Digestive Upset.description: Gastrointestinal distress possibly due to dietary issues, infection, or poisoning
Digestive Upset.recommended_action: Monitor closely for 24 hours. Withhold food for 12 hours but provide water. Contact vet if symptoms persist or worsen.

Leg Injury.description: Injury to leg, possibly sprain, strain, fracture, or joint issue
Leg Injury.recommended_action: Rest the pet and limit activity. Apply cold compress if swelling present. Visit vet within 24-48 hours for examination.

Respiratory Issue.description: Upper respiratory infection, allergies, or breathing difficulty
Respiratory Issue.recommended_action: Monitor breathing pattern. Ensure good air circulation. Schedule vet visit if symptoms persist more than 2-3 days.

Skin Irritation.description: Skin irritation due to allergies, parasites, or infection
Skin Irritation.recommended_action: Check for fleas or ticks. Avoid bathing with harsh products. Schedule vet visit if severe or not improving.

Eye Problem.recommended_action: Keep area clean. Avoid touching or rubbing. Visit vet within 24 hours as eye problems can worsen quickly.

Ear Problem.recommended_action: Keep ears dry. Do not insert anything into ear canal. Schedule vet visit for examination and proper treatment.

Lethargy.description: Unusual tiredness or lack of energy, may indicate underlying illness
Lethargy.recommended_action: Monitor for other symptoms. Ensure adequate water intake. Contact vet if lasts more than 24 hours or accompanied by other symptoms.

Loss of Appetite.description: Decreased or absent appetite, may indicate illness or stress
Loss of Appetite.recommended_action: Try offering favorite foods. Ensure fresh water available. Contact vet if continues more than 24-48 hours.

Excessive Drinking.description: Increased water consumption, may indicate diabetes, kidney issues, or other conditions
Excessive Drinking.recommended_action: Monitor water intake. Note frequency of urination. Schedule vet visit for blood work and urinalysis.

Seizure.description: Abnormal electrical activity in brain causing involuntary movements
Seizure.recommended_action: DO NOT restrain. Move away dangerous objects. Time the seizure. Contact vet immediately, especially if first seizure or lasts over 5 minutes.
